awd_titl_txt: Mechanistic Studies on Fe-Type Nitrile Hydration Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
This award by the Chemistry of Life Processes in the Chemistry Division, is funding Drs. Bennett and Holz from Marquette University to investigate how the enzyme Nitrile hydratase (NHase) transforms chemical groups called nitriles into amides under ambient conditions.  Interestingly, NHases can hydrate not only nitriles found in biological systems but also a wide range of synthetic nitriles.  Hence NHases are extensively used in preparative organic chemistry laboratories and in the industrial production of acrylamide and nicotinamide.  NHases have also proven useful in the cleanup of nitrile-based chemicals and pesticides from the environment and are thus becoming increasingly recognized as a new type of "Green" catalyst.   Knowledge of the mechanisms that underscore their chemical reactivity and applications could provide an impetus for the development of new biocatalysts.  Drs. Bennett and Holz's research use an interdisciplinary experimental approach to gain insight into how nitriles are hydrated by NHases.  Their research and education efforts help promote teaching, training and learning for graduate and undergraduate students, particularly those from underrepresented groups.  Their research also enhances the infrastructure for research and education at Marquette University.  

While the biological roles of NHases are not well understood, they likely include nutrient metabolism, nitrile detoxification and/or nutrient assimilation.  Nitriles are most commonly found in biological systems as cyanoglycosides or cyanolipids, but many plants also produce nitriles such as ricin and beta-cyanoalanine for self-defense purposes.  The major impediment to understanding their biological and bioremediation roles is the lack of understanding of their catalytic mechanism.  Drs. Bennett and Holz provide molecular level insight into the hydration of nitriles by NHases using a combination of kinetics, spectroscopy, biochemistry, computational chemistry, and X-ray crystallography studies.  Answers to three specific questions are sought: (1) What is the transition-state of nitrile hydration? (2) Is a transient disulfide bond between the sulfenic acid cyclic intermediate and the axial alpha-Cys ligand required for catalysis? and (3) What controls metallocenter assembly in Fe-type NHases?  Successful completion of this project enhances our understanding of the catalytic mechanism of NHases and stimulate development of engineered bioremediation catalysts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction.

Nitrile hydratase is an enzyme that converts ("hydrates") nitriles [chemical compounds that contain cyanide (−C≡N) groups] very specifically into a corresponding amide [−C(=O)N=]. These reactions typically involve high energy expenditure (heat), the use of expensive solvents, and produce chemical waste when carried out using traditional synthetic chemistry methods. in addition, the reactions are "dirty," in so far as they do not produce a pure product, which renders the traditional chemistry environmentally unfriendly and unsuited to demanding applications such as pharmaceutical synthesis. Nitrile hydratse, in contrast, catalyzes the reactions in water, at ambient temperature, and produces an extremely pure product. The enzyme is also suited to use as a bioremediation tool for cleaning up nitrile-contaminated land that results from the use of degradation-resistant pesticides.

The long term goal of the work is to replace chemical methods for nitrile hydration with catalysts based on nitrile hydratase, with catalytic properties "tuned" for different reaction substrates. In order to either engineer existing nitrile hydratases for different reactions or to design new catalysts from scratch, it is essential to understand the mechanism of nitrile hydratase in the first place. A further complication is that natively produced nitrile hydratase is initially inactive and additional cellular machinery is required to chemically alter the active site ("post-translational modification") and to insert an essential metal ion (iron or cobalt). Understanding these activation processes and their effects is also, therefore, essential to understanding the mechanism.

High-resolution structural techniques can give a very detailed picture of a molecule like nitrile hydratase on an atomic level. However, these techniques generally require that either the molecules are in the form of a crystal (crystallography) or take a long time, compared to the reaction time, to collect the information (nuclear magnetic resonance). Therefore, while those techniques can be used to define the starting and ending states of a reaction, they cannot generally be applied to the highly dynamic envronment that exists while an enzyme reaction is taking place. We have therefore employed an arsenal of techniques to characterize the chemical species that exist during the reaction.

Techniques.

Mutagenesis. From high-resolution structures of the native enzyme, specific amino acids (that make up the nitrile hydratase enzyme) can be identified that look like they might be important in the reaction (e.g. by their proximity to the metal, or by the fact that they are post-translationally modified), or because they take part in strong interactions. We can use molecular biological techniques ("genetic engineering") to replace these amino acids with more- or less-similar ones and measure the effect on the activity of the enzyme, and on other properties.

Spectrokinetics. We use two forms of spectroscopy to investigate the state of the enzyme under various conditions. Optical spectroscopy measures the absorption of light at different wavelengths (colors), while electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measures the dependence of absorption of microwaves on a changing magnetic field (Figure 1: EPR spectrometer). Optical data can be collected as a function of time over very short time scales using a technique called stopped flow spectrophotometry; substrate is added to the enzyme and the time dependence of optical absorption recorded as the reaction proceeds. EPR, on the other hand, looks at frozen samples at very low temperatures and we have developed a new technique ("cryotrapping") to trap enzymes that are undergoing reaction at various times that can be examined at leisure. EPR provides mostly structural information, while optical stopped-flow provides detailed time-dependence information (kinetics).

Taylor/DFT. Taylor DFT is a method we developed to correlate the results of EPR and optical spectroscopy with structural models for the chemical species. This allows spectroscopy, particularly EPR, to be interpreted in structural terms and identify the intermediates during the reaction.

Results.

Using the techniques described above, and others, we have characterized the pathway for the assembly of the four component subunits of nitrile hydratase in the cell (Figure 2: NHase assembly), and characterized the subsequent sequence of metal insertion, post translational modification, and oxidation of the metal to the active state. In the latter process, high-spin (S = 2) Fe(II) is oxidized first to intermediate-spin (S = 3/2) Fe(III), with partial oxidation of equatorial cysteine residues, and then further oxidation of the cysteines is accompanied by a spin-state change of Fe(III) to low-spin (S = 1/2) and activation of the enzyme.

We have also collected experimental (EPR with DFT) evidence that an intermediate containing a transient disulfide bond accumulates during the reaction; it is not essential for catalysis but lies on an energetically favored pathway.

Finally, we have characterized the rate-limiting step in the reaction - product maturation and release - on an atomic level via EPR and DFT studies.

The results of this work will significantly accelerate the arrival of NHase-based tailored catalysts for pharmaceutical and chemical intermediate synthesis under environmentally-friendly conditions, and for bioremediation.
